meta.content: Photo-Carrier-Guiding Behavior of Vertically Grown MoS2 and MoSe2 in Highly Efficient Low-Light Transparent Photovoltaic Devices on Large-Area Rough Substrates

Two-dimensional MoX2 (X = S, Se) films were vertically grown on highly rough transparent conducting F-doped SnO2 glass substrates for the first time and successfully used as photogenerated carrier-guiding layers (CGLs) in transparent hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) thin film solar cells (TFSCs). The MoSe2 CGL layers could be grown at 530 °C using thermally cracked small Se-molecules on transparent FTO glass substrates and significantly improved cell performance. A transparent cell transmitting 26.0% of visible light with a 20 nm-thick vertically grown MoSe2 CGL showed an outstanding power conversion efficiency of 27.1% at a light intensity of 0.16 mW cm–2 (500 lx; corresponding to normal indoor irradiation). The shunt resistance (Rsh) of the TFSCs reached 32,000 Ω at a light intensity of 7 mW cm–2. An Rsh value this large is essential for low-light photovoltaic (PV) devices to prevent the dissipation of photogenerated carriers. These results strongly demonstrate that transparent a-Si:H-TFSCs with vertically grown MoX2 films should find wide use in building-integrated PV windows or indoor PV applications, as they can generate power even in very low-light environments.

div.div:
Researchers are increasingly focusing on photovoltaic (PV) devices that can be used in environments lacking strong sunlight irradiation. Unfortunately, the power conversion efficiencies (
PCE
s) of solar cells generally decrease sharply in cloudy or indoor environments. For instance, commercially available crystalline silicon (c-Si) solar cells with a
PCE
of 16% at 100 mW cm
–2
in response to air mass 1.5 global (AM 1.5G) spectrum irradiance show a
PCE
of only 5% indoors (i.e., at 0.1 mW cm
–2
).
(1)
This decrease in
PCE
is even more significant for solar cells with low shunt resistance (
R
sh
).
(2,3)

Several research groups have investigated state-of-the-art PV devices in attempts to realize high-
PCE
solar cells under low-light conditions.
(4,5)
An opaque perovskite PV cell adopting PbI
3
showed
PCE
s of 26.9% and 35.2% at light intensities of 400 and 1000 lx, respectively.
(6,7)
Although these PV cells exhibited superior
PCE
s under low-light conditions, there are still several challenges to overcome, including toxicity and instability. Recently, various two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) such as MoS
2
and MoSe
2
have been investigated for use in high-performance solar cells, because 2D TMDC films that are a few nanometers thick can efficiently absorb sunlight and generate a larger photocurrent than much thicker Si or GaAs films.
(8)
Schottky junction and heterojunction cells in which exfoliated MoS
2
and WSe
2
flakes are combined with c-Si have also been reported.
(9−12)
However, the cells did not show noticeably improved performances (including
PCEs
) compared to those of reference solar cells with no TMDC layers. Likewise, the use of MoS
2
films deposited by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) did not improve the cell performance of an n-type MoS
2
/p-type c-Si heterojunction solar cell in comparison to that of conventional c-Si solar cells.
(13)
Furthermore, an Au/220 nm-thick CVD-MoS
2
Schottky junction cell showed a very low
PCE
of 1.8%.
(14)

To implement high performance devices adopting TMDCs, previous studies on the growth of 2D TMDC films have focused on the layer-by-layer planar growth of high-quality films on clean and smooth substrates using CVD,
(15)
metal organic CVD,
(16)
and pulsed-laser deposition.
(17)
However, for solar cell applications, preventing electron dissipation along the horizontal direction and guiding charge carriers along the vertical direction are necessary to increase the
PCE
. We noticed that we could induce the vertical growth of well-aligned 2D TMDC films on rough substrates via the chalcogenization of metal films. 2D films grown perpendicular to the electrode film would be efficient photogenerated carrier-guiding layers (CGLs), as the leakage current along the interface would be limited and the carriers would be directed to the top or bottom electrodes. This would result in increased transport of electrons along the vertically formed 2D planes, improved carrier collection, and decreased carrier dissipation, thus increasing the
R
sh
value.

To investigate this hypothesis, for the first time, we devised a novel structure for transparent hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) thin film solar cells (TFSCs) with a vertical p-i-n diode structure that incorporates a vertically grown MoX
2
(X = S, Se) film as a CGL. MoS
2
and MoSe
2
films have similar electronic and optical properties.
(18−21)
Furthermore, they show similar vertical growth behavior during chalcogenization (which depends on the thickness of the Mo metal precursor) and share similar crystal structures wherein two-dimensional molecular layers are linked by van der Waals forces.
(22)
We fabricated the MoS
2
films on Si substrates at a temperature of 600 °C or higher and MoSe
2
on very rough glass substrates at 530 °C. The reason for using different chalcogen vapors on Si and glass substrates is that the activation energy of Mo metal selenization using Se-vapor is lower than that of Mo metal sulfurization with S-vapor (16.5 ± 3 vs 24.7 ± 3.2 kcal/mol).
(23,24)

Subsequently, we studied the effect of film orientation on carrier transport. The films of vertically oriented 2D structure were grown on both highly flat and very rough substrates because many practical applications of 2D TMDCs require 2D films to be formed on nonideal or rough substrates. For example, to effectively increase light absorption in PV cells, a textured and rough surface is essential in back-reflectors, substrates, and transparent electrodes. However, the growth of 2D TMDCs on such rough substrates has not yet been reported. We focused on the enhancement of a-Si:H-TFSCs as they are nontoxic and have long-term stability in the field. In addition, they are low cost, and there is a natural abundance of the raw materials required to make them. Transparent a-Si:H-TFSCs are also very valuable for use in building-integrated PV (BIPV) and vehicle-integrated PV (VIPV) applications because unlike c-Si solar cells, their transmittance can be adjusted.

Directional growth was achieved with a metal-agglomeration-suppressed growth (MASG) method that we reported previously.
(25)
With typical CVD methods (
Figure
1
a (A)), the MoX
2
films are grown layer-by-layer via vapor phase reactions. However, during the chalcogenization of Mo metal films using cracked small S- and Se-molecules such as S
2
and Se
2
(
Figure
1
a (B)),
(25)
the growth direction (i.e., the film orientation) of the resultant MoS
2
or MoSe
2
film can be readily controlled by adjusting the thickness of the Mo precursor film.
(22,26)
Notably, this results in the growth of vertically aligned MoS
2
or MoSe
2
films when the Mo film is above a critical thickness. For MoS
2
films, this critical thickness is approximately 5 nm. Vertical growth against the substrate can be attributed to strain release, as sulfurization of the metal film causes volume expansion (density: MoS
2
, 5.06 g/cm
3
; MoSe
2
, 6.90 g/cm
3
; Mo, 10.28 g/cm
3
).
(26)

film sulfurized at 570 °C; (c) 90 nm-thick MoS

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We first fabricated MoS
2
films by sulfurizing 2 nm-thick Mo films at a growth temperature of 570 °C in order to confirm their growth mode. The films grew in a layer-by-layer manner parallel to the substrate as shown in the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image in
Figure
1
b. Then, to evaluate the vertical growth behavior, we sulfurized 130 nm-thick Mo films (which are very large compared to the critical thickness for vertical growth) at temperatures of 700 and 500 °C, as shown in
Figure
1
c and d, respectively. The MoS
2
films were vertically grown, and the thickness of the resultant MoS
2
film was dependent on temperature; films of approximately 90 and 20 nm were grown at sulfurization temperatures of 700 and 500 °C, respectively. At both temperatures, only the top portions of the 130 nm-thick Mo films were sulfurized, with the residual Mo layers being approximately 100 and 123 nm thick, respectively. The sulfurization of Mo films therefore resulted in the growth of MoS
2
films that were three times as thick as the consumed Mo-precursor. The near-surface microstructures of the films grown at two different temperatures were very similar. The crystalline planes in the near-surface region were rounded from the release of stress originating from volume expansion during sulfurization. Raman spectroscopic analysis was performed to estimate and compare the qualities of the MoS
2
films.
Figure
1
e clearly shows the E
2g
and A
1g
peaks of thick MoS
2
films grown at 700 and 500 °C, compared to the spectrum of a 6 nm-thick MoS
2
film grown horizontally at 570 °C. The difference in the frequencies of E
2g
and A
1g
peaks increased with the MoS
2
film thickness. Notably, the frequency difference of the 90 nm-thick MoS
2
film of vertically oriented 2D structure was 27.1 cm
–1
, which is larger than the difference of 25 cm
–1
reported for bulk MoS
2
.

Considering their application in PV cells, we formed MoSe
2
films on transparent conducting fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glass substrates (Asahi FTO, T18VU70) for the first time, which are commonly used as transparent electrodes in various TFSCs. The root-mean-square (rms) roughness (σ
rms
) of the FTO film was as high as 38.0 nm (
Figure S1
, Supporting Information). In this experiment, we used the MoSe
2
films because the extent of volume expansion during selenization is greater than that of sulfurization. The Raman spectra in
Figure
2
a are of 5- and 20 nm-thick MoSe
2
films formed on the FTO substrates by selenization at 530 °C. The temperature of 530 °C was chosen because the glass temperature of the FTO glass substrate was lower than 550 °C. The Raman spectra show distinct high-intensity A
1g
and E
2g
peaks and the differences in the frequencies of E
2g
and A
1g
peaks were similar to 5- and 20 nm-thick MoSe
2
films because both films are thicker than 5 monolayers. As shown in the low-resolution TEM image of
Figure
2
b, the 20 nm-thick MoSe
2
film was uniformly grown on FTO glass. The energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS) maps show that Mo and Se were uniformly distributed on the rough FTO film.

div.p:
Figure 2. Raman spectra and cross-sectional HRTEM images of MoSe
2
films grown at 530 °C. (a) Raman spectra of 5- and 20 nm-thick MoSe
2
films formed on FTO glass substrates. (b) TEM image and EDS maps (Sn, Mo, Se) of a 20 nm-thick MoSe
2
layer on FTO glass. (c) Valley region of 5 nm-thick MoSe
2
film. (d) Convex region of 5 nm-thick MoSe
2
film. (e) Valley region on 20 nm-thick MoSe
2
film. (f) Convex region on 20 nm-thick MoSe
2
film. Fast Fourier transform images of the thin films are shown in the insets of c and d.

div.div:
The cross-sectional HRTEM images in
Figure
2
c–f show that both the 5- and 20 nm-thick MoSe
2
films formed conformally on the rough FTO surface. The 5 nm-thick MoSe
2
film (
Figure
2
c and d) comprised horizontal layers that were parallel to the rough surface of the FTO substrate. The thin film had high crystallinity, as demonstrated by the fast Fourier transformation images in the insets of
Figure
2
c and d. The morphology of the 20 nm-thick MoSe
2
film (
Figure
2
e and f) was evidently different, as the MoSe
2
layers were oriented perpendicular to the substrate surface. This vertical growth was more pronounced in the valleys of the FTO substrate (highlighted by the dashed red region in
Figure
2
e) because the volume expansion is hindered in the valleys. The near-surface region (indicated by the blue dashed rectangle) consisted of horizontally grown layers owing to relaxation of volume-expansion-related stress near the surface. In the convex regions of the FTO substrate (
Figure
2
f), the 20 nm-thick film contained a horizontally grown region of about 10 layers. Nevertheless, underneath these horizontal layers, the vertical growth was prominent at the interface between the MoSe
2
film and FTO substrate. As shown in the insets of
Figure
2
c–f, the MoSe
2
layers in both the 5 nm-thick horizontally grown and 20 nm-thick vertically grown films had an interlayer distance of 0.65 nm.

These results strongly indicate that the orientation of the 2D planes can be controlled even on large-area substrates with high roughness. To confirm this, a transparent MoSe
2
film was successfully formed on a large-area (15 × 15 cm) FTO glass substrate. A photograph of the large-area film can be found in
Figure S2
. Raman spectroscopic analysis confirmed the uniformity of the large-area film; the position and fwhm value of the A
1g
peak were very consistent at 25 locations across the film, as demonstrated in
Figure S2b
.

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted to clarify the chemical bonding state of the vertically grown 20 nm-thick MoSe
2
film on the FTO substrate. The spectra and deconvoluted peaks of the Mo 3d photoelectrons at the takeoff angle (θ) of 31° (the sampling depth <5 nm)
(27)
are shown in
Figure
3
a. The binding energies of Mo 3d
5/2
and Mo 3d
3/2
photoelectrons were 229.0 and 232.1 eV, respectively. In the XPS spectrum, the majority of the peaks were sharp Mo
4+
3d peaks and the Mo
6+
3d peaks (230.5 and 233.2 eV) were also found. The presence of MoO
3
might be due to air exposure after selenization and the large surface area due to the very rough FTO film. We observed that the MoSe
2
film thickness formed at 500 °C was 20 nm in
Figure
1
d, and
Figure
2
e and f, the cross-sectional images of the 20 nm-thick MoSe
2
film on FTO, showed no presence of residual Mo metal at the interface. However, for the deep sampling with θ = 90° (sampling depth: <10 nm), Se-deficient Mo peaks are found as shown in
Figure
3
b. The result indicates that the region (MoSe
X
, X < 2) interfaced with FTO must be less resistive compared to stoichiometric MoSe
2
or the oxide-containing surface region. However, the interfacial region did not affect the lateral carrier conductance. The resistivities calculated using the sheet resistances were almost the same for 5 nm-MoSe
2
and 20 nm-MoSe
2
. Hereafter, we define the resistance of the very thin MoSe
2
film as R
S2
and the resistance of the Se-deficient region as R
S3
, and the resistance of 5 nm-thick MoSe
2
is denoted as R
S1
in the equivalent circuit of PV cells (
Figure S6
).

div.p:
Figure 3. Mo 3d XPS spectrum of vertically grown MoSe
2
film. (a) Take-off angle = 31°; (b) 90°.

div.div:
Prior to evaluating the carrier-guiding characteristics of MoX
2
films formed on very rough substrates, we fabricated PV cells on a very flat SiO
2
/Si substrate to understand the phenomena. The inverted-structure a-Si:H-TFSCs (n-i-p configuration) were fabricated on thick vertically grown MoS
2
films (thickness of 90 nm; growth temperature of 700 °C) as CGLs on SiO
2
/Si substrates, as shown in
Figure S3
. Because MoS
2
is an n-type semiconductor, the thickness of the n-type μc-Si layer was varied from 0 to 10 nm to evaluate the function of the MoS
2
layer in the device. The resistivity of the 10 nm-thick n-Si:H layer is in the order of 10
–1
Ω·cm that is much conductive compared to 10 nm-thick MoSe
2
(>10 Ω·cm).
Figure
4
a shows the current density–voltage (
J–V
) characteristic curves of a-Si:H-TFSCs with or without a MoS
2
GCL and with or without n-type μc-Si layers. The performances of the various cells are also listed in
Table S1
. The cells with no n-type μc-Si:H layer (denoted as cells #1-1 (
PCE
= 0.13%) and #2 (
PCE
= 0.62%)) showed very poor performance, suggesting the p-i-n diode structure was nonideal owing to the absence of the n-type μc-Si layer; thus, the vertically grown MoS
2
layer (cell #2) is not a suitable n-type semiconductor layer. However, when vertically grown MoS
2
films were used as CGLs in conjunction with a μc-Si layer (cells #3), the
PCE
improved considerably compared to that of cells with no MoS
2
layer (cells #1 to #1-2), as shown in
Figure
4
a and
Table S1
. Notably, the MoS
2
layer significantly increased the
R
sh
and decreased the series resistance (
R
s
) of the cell, which collectively improved the fill factor (
FF
). For example, in the cells with 10 nm-thick μc-Si layers,
R
sh
increased from 1400 to 4600 Ω and
R
s
decreased from 200 to 81 Ω with the addition of the vertically grown MoS
2
layer (cells #1 and #3, respectively). Furthermore, the open-circuit voltage (
V
OC
) of the cell increased from 0.789 to 0.831 V. To understand this increase in
V
OC
, the energy band structure of the cell with the MoS
2
layer was assessed, as shown in
Figure
4
b. The electron affinities of a-Si:H, n-type μc-Si:H, and MoS
2
are 3.8, 4.1, and 4.3 eV, respectively, and the bandgap energies are 1.8, 1.5, and 1.2 eV, respectively.
(28,29)
Because
V
OC
is proportional to the difference in the Fermi levels of the p- and n-type layers,
V
OC
would increase with the built-in-potential (Δ
V
bi
) owing to the insertion of the thick MoS
2
layer.

films on very flat SiO

2

In order to explain the role of the vertically grown MoS
2
film, the external quantum efficiency (
EQE
) values of a-Si:H-TFSCs on flat substrates were also evaluated, as shown in

. The integrated
EQE
gain by the MoS
2
interlayer was negligibly small for wavelengths of 360–800 nm. Hence, we can conclude that the vertically grown MoS
2
film only contributes to the increase of internal field and
R
sh
and decrease of
R
s
; it does not affect the absorption of sunlight. Also, the relationship between internal field and R

.

results of single diode equivalent-circuit model.

Based on the above-mentioned results, we fabricated transparent a-Si:H-TFSCs with vertically grown MoSe
2
films on rough FTO glass substrates (growth temperature of 530 °C).
Figure
5
a shows a schematic of a carrier-guided (CG)-a-Si:H-TFSC with an inverted structure. The simplified conceptual images of thin CGL and thick CGL were depicted based on the HRTEM images of
Figure
2
c–f. The FTO substrates were the same as those shown in
Figure
2
. To determine the transparency for use in PV windows, the thickness of light-absorbing layers (i-layers) was varied from 100 to 250 nm, and we found that 200 nm-thick i-layer results in the largest figure of merit (FOM) value.
Figure S5a–f
and
Table S2
give photographs and performance details of cells with different i-layer thicknesses, including the
PCE
, average total transmittance (
T
Vis,avg
), FOM, and transmittance (
T
Vis
) spectra. The
T
Vis,avg
values of cells decreased with increasing the i-layer thickness and were ranged from 22.1% to 35.7% in the visible wavelength range (450–800 nm). We defined the FOM as
PCE
/(100 –

We incorporated vertically grown MoX

(X = S, Se) films as CGLs for photogenerated carriers in a-Si:H-TFSCs on highly rough transparent conducting electrodes to improve the performance, especially in low-light environments. To fabricate the CGLs, we successfully controlled the growth direction of MoX
2
films, even on highly rough FTO glass substrates. Both thin and thick MoSe
2
films could be grown conformally on highly rough FTO glasses (σ
rms
= 38.0 nm) by MASG method using cracked small Se-molecules at the growth temperature of 530 °C. By adopting a vertically grown MoSe
2
layer, the carriers were collected effectively along the 2D planes—even on the rough substrate—and the lateral dissipation of carriers was prevented, thus improving
R
sh
and
R
s
. The cell performance improvement with vertically grown 20 nm-thick CGL is more prominent than with the 6 nm-MoSe
2
film in which carriers were primarily transported along the horizontally formed layer. The
R
sh
value was increased to up to 32,000 Ω under blue-rich light intensity of 7 mW cm
–2
. Under very low light intensities (0.16 mW cm
–2
), the highest
PCE
(27.1%) was obtained with a cell adopting a 20 nm-thick vertically grown MoSe
2
CGL, despite its high transmittance (
T
Vis.avg
= 26.0%). A cell with a
PCE
of 27.1% and light transmittance of 26.0% is expected to be equivalent to an opaque solar cell with a
PCE
of 36.6%. The
PCE
of this transparent cell is superior to the record
PCE
values of even opaque PV cells at similar light intensities. The proposed transparent a-Si:H-TFSCs with effective CGLs show great potential for use in PV windows or indoor PV applications under cloudy weather or low light conditions.

Sulfur granules (99.999%, iTASCO), selenium granules (99.999%, iTASCO), and Mo granules (99.99%, LTS) were used as the source materials for the growth of MoS
2
and MoSe
2
films. Mo films, which were deposited using electron beam evaporation, were sulfurized or selenized at growth temperatures of 500, 600, or 700 °C on SiO
2
/Si substrates; or at 530 °C on FTO glass substrates (Asahi FTO, T18VU70). The temperature of S- and Se-cracking zones to generate reactive particles was 950 °C.

Layers of p-type μc-Si:H, intrinsic a-Si:H, and n-type μc-Si:H were deposited using PECVD at a substrate temperature of 200 °C. The thickness of the a-Si:H light-absorbing layer was 250 nm. The precursor gases for depositing Si:H films were SiH
4
and H
2

2
H
6
and PH
3
, respectively. The light absorbing layer was not patterned, and the visible light transmittance of the cell was measured after depositing the top transparent electrode, Ga-doped ZnO (ZnO:Ga). Al as a grid metal was formed on (ZnO:Ga) transparent conducting top electrode. This cell structure, called a coupon cell, has been used frequently in a-Si:H TFSC panels fabricated on opaque stainless steel substrates.

The
J–V
characteristics were measured at room temperature at light intensities of 100 to 20 mW cm
–2
using a solar simulator (ORIEL Instruments). Measuring the cell performances under very low light intensity was not possible using the solar simulator system due to the low current level. Thus, we measured the cells using a parameter analyzer in a black shielding box. For low intensity light irradiation (0.16 and 0.97 mW cm
–2
), the solar cells were measured with a calibrated LED (PHILIPS, LED bulb SS 9-70W 6500K) using 4200scs Keithley. The
EQE
values of the cells were measured using an EQE measurement system (IQE-200, Newport). The aperture area of the solar cells was 0.25 cm
2
.

TEM images of cells were obtained using a TEM system (JEOL, JEM-ARM200F) at an accelerating voltage of 300 kV, and Raman spectroscopy analyses (HORIBA Jobin Yvon, Raman system) were performed using a laser excitation wavelength of 514 nm. The transmittances were measured using an ultraviolet/visible/near-infrared spectrophotometer (Lambda 1050) with an integrating sphere. Nanoscale surface images of the various films were obtained using an AFM system (Park Systems, XE-100).

Two-dimensional (2D), layered transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) can grow in two different growth directions, i.e., horizontal and vertical. In the horizontal growth, 2D TMDC layers grow in planar direction with their basal planes parallel to growth substrates. In the vertical growth, 2D TMDC layers grow standing upright on growth substrates exposing their edge sites rather than their basal planes. The two distinct morphologies present unique materials properties suitable for specific applications, such as horizontal TMDCs for optoelectronics and vertical TMDCs for electrochem. reactions. Precise control of the growth orientation is essential for realizing the true potential of these 2D materials for large-scale, practical applications. In this Letter, we investigate the transition of vertical-to-horizontal growth directions in 2D molybdenum (or tungsten) disulfide and study the underlying growth mechanisms and parameters that dictate such transition. We reveal that the thickness of metal seed layers plays a crit. role in detg. their growth directions. With thick (>∼3 nm) seed layers, the vertical growth is dominant, while the horizontal growth occurs with thinner seed layers. This finding enables the synthesis of novel 2D TMDC heterostructures with anisotropic layer orientations and transport properties. The present study paves a way for developing a new class of 2D TMDCs with unconventional materials properties.

Exptl. detn. of the work function of n-μc-Si:H and n-a-Si:H by the flatband heterojunction technique, revealed that n-μc-Si:H has a higher electron affinity. Thus, in spite of the fact that the difference in activation energy is 0.17 eV, the difference in built-in potential between the two types of cells reduces to about half. Also, modeling of the output characteristics of solar cells, having these two types of N layer, indicates a sharp localization of the field at the N/I interface for the cell with a μc-Si:H N layer. As a consequence, the field in the bulk of the intrinsic layer and, hence, the open-circuit voltage for the two types of cell, remain unchanged.

The semi-cryst. mid-gap photoactive polymer, poly[(2,5-bis(2-hexyldecyloxy)phenylene)-alt-(5,6-difluoro-4,7-di(thiophen-2-yl)benzo[c][1,2,5]thiadiazole)] (PPDT2FBT) and a fullerene deriv., [6,6]-Ph C71 butyric acid Me ester (PC70BM) were used as a photoactive layer. (JSC) and fill factor (FF) values with 280-870 nm thick photoactive layers. The retained JSC and FF values of thick indoor devices were discussed in terms of the parasitic resistance effects based on the single-diode equiv. circuit model. The much lower series/shunt resistance (Rs/RP) ratio was measured with thick photoactive layer (≥280 nm), resulting in negligible decreases in the JSC and FF values even with a 870-nm-thick active layer under the LED condition. Under 1000 lx LED light, the PPDT2FBT:PC70BM device showed an optimum power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 16% (max power d., 44.8μW/cm2) with an open-circuit voltage of 587 mV, a JSC of 117μA/cm2, and a FF of 65.2. A standing wave Fourier transform spectrometer is realized. The spectrometer consists of an ultra thin and partially transparent photodetector and a tunable mirror. The incident light forms a standing wave in front of the mirror, which is sampled by the ultra thin optical detector. The thickness of the photodetector is significantly smaller than the wavelength of the incident light. The spectral information of the incident light is detd. by the Fourier transform of the detector signal. The linear arrangement of the optical detector and the mirror enables the realization of spectrometer arrays and optical cameras with high spectral resoln. For the first time a complete optical model of the standing wave spectrometer is presented and compared with exptl. results. The influence of the design of the optical detector on the performance of the spectrometer is discussed.

A new method to det. the optical absorption coeff. (α) of thin films is presented. The α of hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) based alloys can be accurately detd. from transmittance (T) and reflectance (R) by using T/(1-R), which almost completely eliminates disturbances from the optical interference effect. The method is applicable to any thin films, as long as the film is a single layer. Based on the interference-free α, various methods to det. the optical gap (EOPT) of a-Si:H, a-SiGe:H films are discussed. The (nαhν)1/3 plot and the (αhν)1/3 plot are most suitable for characterizing these films. The well-known (αhν)1/2 plot is less suited for detailed discussion of the EOPT than the cube root plot, because the plot includes a large ambiguity in the EOPT. The effect of the optical interference effect on the detn. of the EOPT is also discussed.
